hero.title: Martina Cardillo
hero.subtitle: Researcher at INAF-IAPS | High-Energy Astrophysics
hero.intro:
Roman astrophysicist, I am a researcher at the Institute of Astrophysics and Space Planetology (IAPS) in Rome, one of the branches of the National Institute for Astrophysics (INAF).
I focus on the acceleration of cosmic rays from galactic sources through gamma-ray astrophysics, which studies the most energetic events in the Universe. My work ranges from the instrument-signal interface in space to the analysis and interpretation of data. I am involved in several national and international collaborations, in particular I am part of the AGILE team (Italian gamma-ray satellite) and the ASTRI Mini-Array project (future network of gamma-ray telescopes).
I love to tell science stories and the Universe in particular, and I do it whenever I can, both through institutional channels (e.g. Gruppo Storie INAF) and personal channels (YouTube: Più Spazio Per Tutti, Facebook: Roma Caput Astri).
I love art in all its forms, Rome, and I am hyperactive, the kind that needs to be calmed down sometimes.

educationExperience.title: Education and Experience
items:
2007 – BSc in Physics (University of Rome Tor Vergata)
Thesis: "The gravitational lensing effect on anisotropies of the cosmic microwave background"
Supervisor: Prof. Amedeo Balbi

2010 – MSc in Sciences of the Universe (University of Rome Tor Vergata)
Thesis: “The Supernova Remnant W28: a study of particle acceleration”
Supervisor: Prof. Marco Tavani

2013 – PhD in Astronomy (University of Rome Tor Vergata)
Thesis: “The origin of cosmic rays in supernova remnants: new challenges after a breakthrough”
Supervisor: Prof. Marco Tavani
The thesis received the ARAP Prize (Associazione Romana per le Astro-Particelle)

2014–2017 – Post-doc at INAF – Arcetri Astrophysical Observatory (Florence)
I worked in Pasquale Blasi's high-energy group on theoretical models of cosmic-ray acceleration in supernova remnants.
2017–2021 – Post-doc at INAF–IAPS - I worked mainly on gamma-ray data analysis from the AGILE satellite and modeling, and I started my activity within the ASTRI collaboration.

2021–present – Tenured researcher at INAF–IAPS - I consolidated my role within the ASTRI collaboration, started supervising PhD student Alan Sunny, and began independent work on multi-frequency and multi-messenger studies of Galactic PeVatrons, also with the support of external collaborations (e.g., Dr Jagdish Joshi at ARIES and Dr Gabriela Castelletti at CONICET-Universidad De Buenos Aires)

research.title: Scientific Activities and Collaborations
research.body: I have long experience in modeling and data analysis of cosmic-ray acceleration processes and gamma-ray emission from galactic sources, especially supernova remnants. - I am lead co-author of the paper Giuliani, Cardillo et al. (2011), which provided the first evidence of cosmic rays in a supernova-remnant shock thanks to the AGILE satellite. - As a member of the AGILE team, I received the Bruno Rossi Prize for the discovery of gamma flares from the Crab Nebula (2012). - I work on acquisition and data analysis from satellites and Cherenkov detectors. - Within the ASTRI Mini-Array collaboration I am co-coordinator of several working groups: Data Processing System working package, Scientific Analysis Working Group, and Science Pevatron Working Group. I am involved in several projects and collaborations, including AGILE, ASTRI Mini-Array, CTAO, LST-1 and I am also an associate member of MAGIC. I strongly believe in the importance of scientific outreach, and for this reason my commitment is always active and passionate. You can find all the activities I carry out on the dedicated page.

supervision.title: Thesis & PhD requests
supervision.bodyIntro: I am available to supervise BSc/MSc theses and PhD projects on gamma-ray data analysis and modeling of cosmic-ray acceleration in galactic sources, and related topics. If you want to propose a project or see if we share a topic, write me: I reply (almost) at the speed of light.
supervision.bodyDetail: Since 2023 I have supervised Alan Sunny, a PhD student of the 39th cycle in Astronomy, Astrophysics and Space Science at the Universities of Tor Vergata and La Sapienza in Rome.
